msgSnippet: Hi think that using a mediator could guarantee you from separating the mechanism for handling data that lies deep in the core of your application from the
messageBody:
Hi think that using a mediator could guarantee you from separating the
mechanism for handling data that lies deep in the "core" of your application
from the GUI details, but sometimes the behavior of a single form can be
driven by a many-state state machine (so being very complex) and some
transitions should rely on some other data liyng somewhere else in the depth
of the application.
Here the problem arises.

One example should be if I would test my GUI behavior when something
somewhere else changes.

I.e. I'm editing some fields to be sent later to a server and the connection
goes down. Ok the mediator can do the great part of the job but what if my
current form should let me save the data into a file in order to retrieve
them later? That kind of knowledge lies inside the form (it's its own
responsibility, above all!) while the constraints come from the outer world.

Hi,

On 6/11/02 7:28 AM, "Michael Silverstein" <msilverstein@...>
wrote:

>
>
> Bob Koss [mailto:koss@...] wrote:
>> But if we use Mediator to decouple the gui controls, we may as
>> well delegate
>> everything to the Mediator and leave the gui stupid. The Mediator can be
>> unit tested just like any other class, and doesn't need the gui since all
>> communication is done through interfaces.
>
> That notwithstanding, you still need to test the connection between the
> mediator and your GUI. There's still plenty of room for error there.


I'm trying to understand your concern. I can test that the Mediator send the
right message with the right parameters at the right time. The code in the
gui (let's say a Dialog box just to be concrete) that responds to this
message is one or two lines of code which IMO, can't break.

Can you show me in a few lines of code where there is room for error between
the Mediator and the gui/dialog/whatever?
